author: By Juliet Macur
title: Megan Rapinoe Is Not Going Quietly
description: Relegated to a reserve role in her fourth World Cup, the outspoken U.S. forward said she has plenty left to give. And that she’s still expecting to win it all.
content: Sitting on the bench as her United States team played at the Women’s World Cup last week, Megan Rapinoe was sure that she was in the wrong spot. She was just as sure that her coach, Vlatko Andonovski, should see that, and fix it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: A New Recipe for a Very Old Hummus
description: Ligaya Mishan’s medieval hummus blends chickpeas and tahini with toasted seeds and spices, hazelnuts and pistachios, preserved lemon and fresh mint.
content: Good morning. There’s some very nice writing about recipes in The New York Times Magazine this week, not surprisingly under the byline of Ligaya Mishan. Her subject is a hummus recipe (above), dating back to 13th century Syria, that Lucien Zayan of the Invisible Dog Art Center in Brooklyn served at a dinner series he runs, la Salle A Manger.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tyler Kepner
title: The Mets Trade a Star and Embrace the Future
description: Max Scherzer is headed to the Texas Rangers as the Mets, the most expensive team in M.L.B. history, acknowledge that you can’t buy your way to the top.
content: The most expensive roster in major league history was a failure. The Mets’ superfan owner, Steven A. Cohen, committed nearly half a billion dollars this season to learn a timeless lesson easily forgotten when pursuing World Series glory: Money guarantees nothing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: SUNDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike McIntire
title: The Secret History of Gun Rights: How Lawmakers Armed the N.R.A.
description: They served in Congress and on the N.R.A.’s board at the same time. Over decades, a small group of legislators led by a prominent Democrat pushed the gun lobby to help transform the law, the courts and views on the Second Amendment.
content: Long before the National Rifle Association tightened its grip on Congress, won over the Supreme Court and prescribed more guns as a solution to gun violence — before all that, Representative John D. Dingell Jr. had a plan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Declan Walsh
title: West African Nations Threaten Military Action Unless Niger Coup Is Undone
description: A demand for a restoration of democracy echoed calls by the United States and France, major security allies of Niger.
content: West African leaders on Sunday threatened military action against Niger, where soldiers seized power in a coup on Wednesday, unless the country’s democratically elected president is restored to office within a week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Holpuch
title: Officer Convicted After Train Hits Patrol Car With Handcuffed Woman Inside
description: A Colorado police officer was found guilty of two misdemeanors after leaving the woman trapped inside a patrol car on active railroad tracks.
content: A Colorado police officer was found guilty of two misdemeanors on Friday after facing charges for putting a handcuffed woman in a patrol car that was parked on active railroad tracks and then struck by a freight train.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carlotta Gall
title: Amid the Counterattack’s Deadly Slog, a Glimmer of Success for Ukraine
description: Recapturing the village of Staromaiorske was such welcome news for the country that President Volodymyr Zelensky announced it himself. But formidable Russian defenses have stymied progress elsewhere.
content: For 10 days, Ukrainian marines fought street by street and house by house to recapture the southeastern village of Staromaiorske, navigating artillery fire, airstrikes and hundreds of Russian troops.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah A. Topol, Adrienne Hurst, Aaron Esposito, John Woo, Dan Farrell and Steven Szczesniak
title: The Sunday Read: ‘The America That Americans Forget’
description: As tensions with China mount, the U.S. military continues to build up Guam and other Pacific territories — placing the burdens of imperial power on the nation’s most ignored and underrepresented citizens.
content: On the weekends, when Roy Gamboa was a little boy, his grandfather would wake him before dawn. He would pour some coffee into a bowl of rice, and that would be the boy’s breakfast. Roy knew better than to question anything; he sat quietly in his grandfather’s truck as they rumbled down the big hill from their village, Hågat, to Big Navy, as the U.S. Naval Base in Guam is known. They passed through the military gates, along a dirt road and onto the shore of a little cove, next to one of America’s deepest harbors, where skipjacks flipped out of the aquamarine water. The boy noodled with seashells as his grandfather cast. When his grandfather caught a fish, he would unhook it and throw it on the ground, and Roy would snatch it up and quickly stuff it, still wriggling, in the bag. If the fish weren’t biting at one spot, they packed up and moved to another. No one from the Navy ever stopped the old man and the young boy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicole Sperling
title: Judge Rejects Johnson & Johnson’s Effort to Limit Talc-Related Liabilities
description: A bankruptcy court’s ruling was the second time the company was rebuffed in its attempt to settle thousands of lawsuits that claim its products caused cancer.
content: For the second time this year, a court has ruled against Johnson & Johnson’s effort to use a bankruptcy case to limit its exposure to tens of thousands of lawsuits that claim its talcum powder products caused cancer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Morgan Campbell
title: Terence Crawford Knocks Out Errol Spence in One-Sided Bout
description: The rare matchup of two of the best pound-for-pound boxers ended with Crawford dominating the whole fight.
content: Terence Crawford turned the most significant boxing match of the year into a bruising lesson in the sweet science, dropping Errol Spence Jr. three times en route to a ninth-round knockout on Saturday night to become the undisputed champion at 147 pounds.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Jacobs
title: ‘Tom Lake’ Finds Ann Patchett in a Chekhovian Mood
description: This time the celebrated novelist spins the cozy tale of a former actress, her three daughters and their rueful memories. There’s a cherry orchard, too.
content: Are you in possession of a hammock? A creaky old porch swing? A bay window with built-in seating? If not, Ann Patchett’s new novel, “Tom Lake,” will situate you there mentally. I wouldn’t be surprised if it put your fitness tracker on the fritz, even if you amble around listening to Meryl Streep read the audio version.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Diamond
title: A Word That Never Goes Out of Style
description: Style isn’t just about fashion or punctuation. It’s “a way of moving through the world.”
content: For the November 2018 issue of The New York Times for Kids, the photographer Marcy Swingle took portraits of 48 of the “coolest” children in New York City. “No matter my subjects’ age,” Ms. Swingle wrote, “one thing remains the same: Some people just have style.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jay Root
title: New York City Had a Migrant Crisis. It Hired a Covid Expert to Help.
description: DocGo, a medical services firm, has moved hundreds of asylum seekers outside the city as part of its no-bid $432 million contract. Many say they have been threatened and lied to.
content: Lured by the promise of jobs, legal assistance and a more welcoming environment, hundreds of asylum seekers have boarded buses headed north to Albany, in search of a life better than they had found in New York City.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amy Larocca
title: What Is It About Montecito?
description: Trying to understand the allure of a place that’s home to Oprah, the self-exiled royals, a celebrity juicer, Katy Perry’s dad — and the New American Dream.
content: Are there Americans who don’t have fantasies about a better life in California? About gold in the rivers, giant fruit in the yards and a hardcore, neon sunset every single night? The collective westward yearn is endlessly evolving and migrating around the very big state, sometimes dampened but never entirely silenced by stories about natural disasters and inner-city crime.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alissa J. Rubin and Bryan Denton
title: A Climate Warning from the Cradle of Civilization
description: How extreme temperatures and dwindling water are pushing the Fertile Crescent toward the brink.
content: The word itself, Mesopotamia, means the land between rivers. It is where the wheel was invented, irrigation flourished and the earliest known system of writing emerged. The rivers here, some scholars say, fed the fabled Hanging Gardens of Babylon and converged at the place described in the Bible as the Garden of Eden.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Weisman
title: A Left-Right Alliance Puts Iowa’s CO2 Pipelines on the Presidential Agenda
description: Liberal environmentalists and conservative landowners, led by the former congressman Steve King, are pressuring Republican candidates to oppose three Midwestern pipelines.
content: Emma Schmidt, a lifelong environmental activist in Rockwell City, Iowa, had long searched for potent allies in her fight against a massive carbon dioxide pipeline planned for her state.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Martell
title: A Relationship That Transcends Analytics
description: Adding a new catcher at the trading deadline is a fairly rare occurrence. One reason for that is the time it takes to bond with a pitching staff.
content: The weeks leading up to Major League Baseball’s trading deadline are always tense. Every team has to evaluate where they are in the standings, what the organization’s long-term outlook is and how much could be changed by acquiring a few veterans.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Goldberg
title: We’re in the Era of the ‘Top Gun’ C.E.O.
description: Work is war — or it can feel that way to certain executives. To meet the moment, they’re getting in a cockpit.
content: “Your company is about to go on a rescue,” declared Christian Boucousis, who goes by the name Boo at work. “One of your company members went out to do reconnaissance and was shot down. Now you’re going to rescue your teammate and bring them home.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Javier C. Hernández
title: A Trombonist on a Mission to Break Barriers in Classical Music
description: Hillary Simms is the first woman to become a member of the American Brass Quintet. She says the field needs more role models.
content: As a child growing up in rural Canada, the trombonist Hillary Simms did not realize that women were scarce among players of brass instruments — the tuba, the French horn, the trumpet and the trombone. Her music teachers were largely women, and so were many of her peers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Lyall
title: Belly of the Beast
description: In Daniel Kraus’s “Whalefall,” a scuba diver, inadvertently swallowed alive by a 60-ton sperm whale, tries to escape.
content: In marine biology, a whale fall is the body of a dead whale that has slowly descended to the bottom of the ocean. Scavengers strip its flesh, crustaceans and other creatures colonize its skeleton and its decaying bones help sustain countless organisms for years to come, part of the delicate balance of the undersea ecosystem.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michelle Cottle
title: How Trump Could Wreck Things for Republicans in 2024
description: The governor’s race in New Hampshire offers a window into the ways Trump could complicate the lives of down-ballot G.O.P. candidates.
content: Things just got a whole lot more interesting in New Hampshire politics. Just below the presidential churn, the governor’s race in the politically quirky Granite State has some superjuicy drama percolating — the kind that offers a vivid reminder of just how much trouble Donald Trump stands to cause for his party in 2024.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Feuer, Maggie Haberman and Ben Protess
title: Minor Characters Emerge to Play Key Roles in Trump Documents Case
description: Carlos De Oliveira and Walt Nauta, who were hired by former President Donald J. Trump despite past troubles, rely on him for their legal fees — and are now his co-defendants.
content: In the early 2000s, Carlos De Oliveira was a valet and handyman at Mar-a-Lago, parking cars and doing odd jobs at Donald J. Trump’s private club and residence in Florida for not much more than $10,000 a year, court records show.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mujib Mashal and Suhasini Raj
title: Could Ethnic Conflict in India Become an Issue Modi Cannot Ignore?
description: India’s opposition is trying to force the prime minister to address the violence in Manipur, which has killed more than 150 people and displaced 60,000 others.
content: It’s been business as usual lately for Prime Minister Narendra Modi of India: red carpet trips abroad, ribbon-cuttings and political rallies at home.
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘I Opened the Envelope and Found Three Pictures of Me in an Incubator’
description: An unlikely source of baby photos, a sharp jab to the ribs and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.
content: Dear Diary:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Fahy
title: Germany is sidestepping the messiness present in other groups.
description: Germany is comfortably winning Group H after trouncing Morocco, 6-0, in its opening match. Having reached the quarterfinals every previous tournament, this year looks to be no different thanks to a favorable draw.
content: Germany is comfortably winning Group H after trouncing Morocco, 6-0, in its opening match. Having reached the quarterfinals every previous tournament, this year looks to be no different thanks to a favorable draw.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Penelope Green
title: SunRay Kelley, Master Builder of the Counterculture, Dies at 71
description: The go-to guru for those seeking their dream yurt, spiritual retreat or treehouse, he brought forth his handmade structures like a wizard with a chain saw.
content: SunRay Kelley, the barefoot maverick builder of fantastical handmade castles, yurts, temples, spirit lodges, tree houses, pavilions and structures so fanciful that they defied conventional building typologies, died on July 16 in Sedro-Woolley, Wash. He was 71.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: In Sweltering Border Towns, Water Cutoffs Add to Misery
description: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, July 30, 2023.
content: “You see the carwashes using all of this water, but there is no water for a mother and her two children? How is that possible?”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Lee Myers and Kellen Browning
title: Russia Takes Its Ukraine Information War Into Video Games
description: Propaganda is appearing in Minecraft and other popular games and discussion groups as the Kremlin tries to win over new audiences.
content: Russian propaganda is spreading into the world’s video games.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By George Gene Gustines
title: But Who Gets the Comic Books?
description: When collectors die, their families face a lot of decisions, including what to do with a hundred Superman figurines.
content: “More times than I can remember, a spouse or child has said to me, ‘If he wasn’t dead, I’d kill him all over again for leaving me with this mess,’” said Greg Rohan, the president of Heritage Auctions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rebecca Carballo
title: ‘X’ on Twitter’s Headquarters Faces Investigation Over Permit Violations
description: An “X” sign, installed on the roof of the company’s headquarters in San Francisco as part of its rebranding, lacked proper permits, officials said.
content: An “X” sign installed on Twitter’s San Francisco headquarters on Friday as part of the company’s rebranding is under investigation by the city for lacking proper permits, according to officials.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Cochrane, Amy Harmon, Anemona Hartocollis and Anna Betts
title: The Legacy Dilemma: What to Do About Privileges for the Privileged?
description: Alumni of many colleges are wrestling with whether the practice of legacy admissions should survive after the Supreme Court gutted race-based admissions programs.
content: When Kathleen James-Chakraborty received her acceptance letter to Yale on April 17, 1978, there was little doubt in her mind that a crucial factor helped secure her spot: Her father and two great-grandfathers had all attended the school before her.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isaac Aronow
title: Today’s Wordle Review
description: Our columnist reviews the day’s puzzle. Warning: Contains spoilers!
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This article contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brooks Barnes
title: ‘Haunted Mansion’ Extends Disney’s Box Office Cold Streak
description: “Barbie” and “Oppenheimer” continued to dominate, as “Haunted Mansion” tried to break through without the promotional help of its stars, who are on strike.
content: Disney’s “Haunted Mansion” took in about $24 million at the weekend box office, a comatose result for a movie that cost at least $200 million to make and market.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: July 30, 2023
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Sunday, July 30, 2023.
content: An article last Sunday about Califor­nia legislators working to form a renters’ caucus misstated the num­ber of tenants in the state. It is about 17 million residents, not 17 million households.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Caron
title: How to Feel Happier at Work When You Have the Urge to Quit
description: Because sometimes leaving isn’t the best option.
content: When Minda Harts was 35 and working as a fund-raiser, she was feeling increasingly frustrated. Her manager viewed her as a “utility player” who could be “put anywhere” and still get the job done. She wanted to be a leader.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Zimmer
title: A Theory of Childbirth’s Evolution May Not Be What You’re Expecting
description: Scientists are revisiting an influential theory that the evolution of big brains made human childbirth risky.
content: It’s a question on every new parent’s exhausted mind: Why are babies born so helpless? In 1960, an American anthropologist laid out an influential explanation rooted in human evolution.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Livia Albeck-Ripka
title: Homeless Camps Are Being Cleared in California. What Happens Next?
description: One of the state’s largest homeless encampments was recently shut down in Oakland, but that didn’t stop the problem of homelessness.
content: John Janosko recently moved into a tiny cabin in Oakland, Calif., after the city and the state shut down the sprawling homeless encampment where he had resided for most of the past eight years. City officials consider the shed-size unit — with a bed, a folding chair, a desk and a mini fridge — a vast improvement over the makeshift shelters that once sat beneath a freeway.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lewis Hyde
title: It Was Never Just About the Butterflies
description: Make very little of yourself if you wish to see clearly. Shut up, deeply, if you wish to hear.
content: If you have ever gone bird watching, or looked for wildflowers or mushrooms, or hunted for deer or rabbits, you will know the strange enchantment of searching for nature’s hidden treasures. I myself first knew it in childhood, hunting for butterflies in the farm fields of Connecticut, a pursuit that sadly ended when my family moved to Pittsburgh and the dense fogs of puberty and higher education descended upon me, obscuring the swallowtails and skippers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Haberman and Shane Goldmacher
title: Trump Team Creates Legal-Defense Fund to Cover His Allies’ Bills
description: With investigations and legal fees piling up, a fund is planned to help witnesses and defendants. The former president’s legal bills are not expected to be included, however.
content: Former President Donald J. Trump’s team is creating a legal-defense fund to handle some of the crush of legal bills stemming from the investigations and criminal indictments involving him and a number of employees and associates, according to two people with knowledge of the matter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eduardo Medina
title: 2 Dead and 2 Hurt in Midair Collision at Wisconsin Airport
description: The collision happened at an Oshkosh, Wis., airport that was hosting an air show on Saturday. The victims were attendees of the show, an official said.
content: Two people died and two others were injured after a helicopter and a gyrocopter collided in midair on Saturday at a Wisconsin airport that was hosting an air show, the authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Goldbaum and Zia ur-Rehman
title: At Least 43 Killed in Blast at Political Rally in Pakistan
description: An explosion at a political rally on Sunday in northwest Pakistan killed dozens of people and injured 200 more, officials said, the latest sign of the deteriorating security situation in Pakistan, where some militant groups have become more active over the past two years.
content: An explosion at a political rally on Sunday in northwest Pakistan killed at least 43 people and wounded 200 more, officials said, the latest sign of the deteriorating security situation in the country, where some militant groups have become more active over the past two years since finding a haven in neighboring Afghanistan under the Taliban administration there.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Morgan Campbell
title: Terence Crawford Stands Alone at the Top of Boxing
description: After becoming the first male boxer to hold all four major titles in two different weight classes, Crawford, 35, said he would assess what’s next.
content: Terence Crawford emerged from the locker room at T-Mobile Arena in Las Vegas late on Saturday night, walked the long aisle to the arena floor, then scaled the steps to the boxing ring one more time.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: Your Monday Briefing: Dozens Dead in Pakistan
description: Also, Narendra Modi’s silence on Manipur and Iraq’s climate destruction.
content: At least 43 people were killed in the country’s northwest yesterday, officials said, the latest sign of the deteriorating security situation in Pakistan. The death toll is expected to rise: At least 200 people were wounded.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jazmine Ulloa
title: Nuts-and-Bolts Conservatism From Nikki Haley
description: In her stump speech, the former governor calls for common sense and experience in the White House, leaving crowds wanting more.
content: Nikki Haley is not as loud or fiery as some of her pulpit-pounding rivals for the Republican presidential nomination. But her pleas for common sense and experience in the White House often leave crowds wanting more.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Horowitz
title: ‘We Are a Romantic Country’: On the Set of a Steamy Hit in Italy
description: Italy falls for “Mare Fuori,” a television melodrama about the inmates of a juvenile detention center who pass the time making out — when not scowling at or occasionally stabbing one another.
content: Before dawn, the teenage girls convened outside the Naples Navy base where the wildly popular Italian television show “Mare Fuori” is filmed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Kelly and David Perlmutt
title: Inside the Party Switch that Blew Up North Carolina Politics
description: Tricia Cotham, a Democrat who supported abortion rights, was encouraged to run for a state House seat by powerful Republicans. After she was elected, she joined them and delivered a G.O.P. supermajority.
content: When Tricia Cotham, a former Democratic lawmaker, was considering another run for the North Carolina House of Representatives, she turned to a powerful party leader for advice. Then, when she jumped into the Democratic primary, she was encouraged by still other formidable allies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicole Sperling
title: Judge Dismisses Trump’s $475 Million Defamation Suit Against CNN
description: The network’s statements were opinion, the ruling said, and did not support a claim of libel and slander.
content: A federal judge has dismissed a $475 million defamation lawsuit that former President Donald J. Trump filed against CNN, ruling that all of the CNN statements that Mr. Trump cited were opinion and, therefore, Mr. Trump could not sue for defamation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Theo Baker
title: The Research Scandal at Stanford Is More Common Than You Think
description: Scientific journals need to harden their defenses against research manipulation.
content: There are many rabbit holes on the internet not worth going down. But a comment on an online science forum called PubPeer convinced me something might be at the bottom of this one. “This highly cited Science paper is riddled with problematic blot images,” it said. That anonymous 2015 observation helped spark a chain of events that led Stanford’s president, Marc Tessier-Lavigne, to announce his resignation this month.
source.name: The New York Times

title: L.G.B.T.Q. in America: ‘We Are Never Going Back to the Closet Darkness’
description: Responses to an essay by Jane Coaston and a news article. Also: No Labels; fallout from the Trinity test; climate deniers.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor
title: Trump Threatens Republicans Who Don’t Help Him Exact Vengeance
description: Casting Republicans as meek, former President Donald J. Trump said members of his party should pursue investigations against Democrats — or risk losing their seats.
content: Former President Donald J. Trump lashed out at Republicans in Congress while campaigning in Pennsylvania on Saturday, threatening members of his party who do not share his appetite for pursuing corruption investigations against President Biden and his family — and for retribution.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrés R. Martínez and Anton Troianovski
title: Russia Says 2 Drones Hit Buildings in Moscow in Latest Wave of Attacks
description: The strike was the third in the past week in Moscow, a sign of how no city in Russia or Ukraine appears to be safe from the war. Russia blamed Ukraine, which has yet to comment.
content: The Russian Defense Ministry said on Sunday that Ukrainian forces had fired at least three drones at Moscow, the latest in a wave of attacks in Russia demonstrating that few places are off limits after more than 17 months of war.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabetta Povoledo
title: Excavations Uncover Hints of Nero’s Theater in Rome, and Much More
description: A dig at a palace set to become a hotel has unearthed traces of a theater that archaeologists hypothesize was built by Nero, the emperor with a disputed reputation for tyranny and debauchery.
content: At a 15th-century palace that is steps from the Vatican and set to become a luxury hotel, archaeologists did what they always do in Rome, an ancient city thick with buried treasures.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By William K. Rashbaum
title: A Federal Food Safety Case Reveals Latest New York City Rat Horror Story
description: Prosecutors reached a settlement with the operator of a meat and poultry warehouse that had been infested with rodents before it was shuttered.
content: When federal investigators arrived at a meat and poultry warehouse on Allen Street in Chinatown in April 2022, they found what might have been New York City’s best-fed rat population.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tish Harrison Warren
title: The State of Evangelical America
description: A conversation with Russell Moore, the theologian and editor of Christianity Today.
content: There are few evangelical Christians who have gotten as much media coverage or criticism in the last decade as Russell Moore. He previously served as the president of the Ethics and Religious Liberty Commission, the policy wing of the Southern Baptist Convention, and became a prominent evangelical voice opposing a Trump presidency. Moore is currently the editor in chief of Christianity Today, which The Times’s Jane Coaston called “arguably the most influential Christian publication” in the United States. I asked Moore if he would speak to me about the evangelical movement and his new book, “Losing Our Religion: An Altar Call for Evangelical America.” This interview has been edited and condensed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Miller
title: Finally on Top, the Rangers Hope to Stay There
description: Texas’ big spending was finally paying off, but a July swoon had the Houston Astros closing in. Will the Rangers’ trade for Max Scherzer be enough to win the A.L. West?
content: Marcus Semien was a sophomore infielder at the University of California, Berkeley, in 2010 when Bruce Bochy was managing the San Francisco Giants to their first of three World Series titles in five years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Corbin
title: Shade of Color
description: David Litman and Andrea Carla Michaels make a strong case together.
content: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues | Solving Tip
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tina Cordova
title: What ‘Oppenheimer’ Doesn’t Tell You About the Trinity Test
description: As a new generation of Americans learns about the world’s first nuclear test, the people who lived through it are being left out of the story again.
content: July is a hard month for a lot of us here in New Mexico, where thousands of people’s lives were upended by the test of the world’s first nuclear bomb. The events of July 16, 1945, weigh heavily on us. And why wouldn’t they? They changed everything. The people of New Mexico were the first human test subjects of the world’s most powerful weapon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Susan Burton
title: What Women Endure
description: For many women, tolerating pain is the only choice they have.
content: In medical settings, it is common for women’s pain to be ignored or dismissed. In other cases, it is not properly treated.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Jacobson
title: A Deeply Human Experience You’ll Never Have on Your Couch
description: The Barbenheimer phenomenon reminded us of something we’d forgotten: The moviegoing experience is about so much more than what’s onscreen.
content: It seemed like a miracle. The Cobble Hill Cinemas, a neighborhood joint that opened in the 1920s as the Lido and that served for decades as a venue for B-movie action films, was packed on what would ordinarily be a dead Monday night — and without a single Lazy Boy recliner, goat cheese pizza or other modern enticement in sight. I was there with 200 or so other patrons, a gloriously mixed crowd, to see “Oppenheimer,” one half of the Barbenheimer cultural moment. When the bomb finally went off in the New Mexico desert — this fulcrumatic moment in our species’ history — it was beheld simultaneously, an exhilarating common experience, which is exactly what the movie house is supposed to deliver. In the end, it didn’t matter if you liked the picture or not. What mattered is that we’d seen it together.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Bazelon
title: In Israel, High Stakes for High Court: Democracy’s Fate
description: From Hungary to India to Brazil, how judges responded to attacks on their independence helped decide whether would-be autocrats prevailed in constraining the courts.
content: When the Israeli Supreme Court announced Wednesday that it would review a new law designed to curb its power, it set up a complicated choice for itself. Will it directly confront the elected branches of government by overturning the law? Or will it instead rule in such a way that sidesteps a constitutional crisis?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Marchese
title: Alok Vaid-Menon Is ‘Fighting for Trans Ordinariness’
description: The activist and social media star just wants to worry about basic things, not their safety.
content: The activist and social media star just wants to worry about basic things, not their safety.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press and Reuters
title: Coup Supporters Attack the French Embassy in Niger
description: People who back the coup waved Russian flags in Niger’s capital and called for French troops to withdraw from the country.
content: People who back the coup waved Russian flags in Niger’s capital and called for French troops to withdraw from the country.
source.name: The New York Times
